definitions.definition: a large deep hole in the ground

examples.text: We dug a deep pit in the yard.
The body had been dumped in a pit.
The human mind is a dark, bottomless pit.

definitions.definition: a deep hole in the ground from which minerals are dug out

examples.text: They extract the mineral from open pits and underground mines.

definitions.definition: a place underground where coal is dug

examples.text: He went down the pit *(= started work as a )* when he left school.
Most boys in the town worked in the pits.
There's no more work in these pit villages.

definitions.definition: a small shallow hole in the surface of something, especially a mark left on the surface of the skin by some disease, such as chickenpox
a hard shell containing the nut or seed in the middle of some types of fruit
definitions.labels: (especially North American English)especially in British English

definitions.definition: a place near the track where cars can stop for fuel, new tyres, etc. during a race
the place in a theatre just in front of the stage where the orchestra sits and plays for an opera, a ballet, etc.
an armpit (= the part of the body under the arm where it joins the shoulder)
the area of a stock exchange where a particular product is traded
to be very bad or the worst example of something
a thing or situation which seems to have no limits or seems never to end

examples.text: There isn't a bottomless pit of money for public spending.
the bottomless pit of his sorrow

definitions.definition: the bottom of the stomach where people say they feel strong feelings, especially fear

examples.text: He had a sudden sinking feeling in the pit of his stomach.
I felt a sickening feeling in the pit of my stomach when I saw the ambulance.

wordOrigin: noun senses 1 to 4 and noun senses 6 to 9,Old English pytt, of West Germanic origin; related to Dutch put and German Pfütze, based on Latin puteus ‘well, shaft’. noun sense 5 mid 19th cent.: apparently from Dutch; related to pith.
